note.body: I think you should go one step further: don't set explicit compat= setting, just set <target><features><lazy_refcounts/>, and libvirt will set compat=1.1 automatically for you. This is what we've done in virt-manager since feb 2014 without issue. lazy_refcounts is an additional performance enhancement, it's mentioned in that original issue

events.target_title: Do not generate USB input devices for Windows 2000 VMs

note.body: For x86+qemu, virt-manager uses a USB tablet if osinfo reports it as supported, otherwise we use qemu/libvirt defaults, which is ps2. The boxes bug about win8+ps2 being slow is not anything I had heard in virt-manager, nor gerd hoffman who maintains the input layer in qemu. So I think that win8 issue is worth a retest, and if so discuss it with qemu devs... could have been a transient qemu bug for all we know

Also see related discussion from
https://github.com/awesomeWM/awesome/pull/2129#issuecomment-348152337
to
https://github.com/awesomeWM/awesome/pull/2129#issuecomment-348476115

note.body:
> Everybody just some random stuff that works well enough and hopes it doesn't break.

that's actually a problem which is discussed by that link from my message above. But I don't think what it's appropriate here to blame neither app nor theme developers for not conforming the spec which doesn't exist. If you take a look on Firefox sources linked in that discussion you should feel how much pain the devs who were struggling with that had to feel in the process :-) For example in GTK+ 2 it was at least some few basic values which were existing in every theme (however i don't know if there was a spec on that). And since GTK+ 4 is claming to be more stable than 3 i would expect from it to have some stable spec on this part.

By the way despite the research i did during implementing GTK StyleContext support in Awesome WM I am also working on this GTK+ theme-related project: https://github.com/actionless/oomox/. So during developing/debugging it from both sides of application and theme developer that's quite evident to me what this part of the spec is lacking.

events.target_title: Make GtkCssProvider API less confusing

note.body:
the thing it what because of missing spec theme developers are just looking how it's made in other themes and copying the same style context vars and mb changing them more or less

and next app developers just getting crazy because every theme have it's own stylecontext spec which are very similar to each but not the same, i think it's like OCD hell looks like.

So i don't really know how does the current situation is related to 'freedom of expression'. And also I don't see how having minimal required list of stylecontext variables would limit any kind of artistic freedom for the theme developers.

> For example, I would not have any support for GTK themes in Firefox but just draw stuff in a way that kinda matches how Gnome looks.

good try to play like you never heard of Xfce, Mate, Cinnamon, LXDE and others ;-)

events.target_title: Make GtkCssProvider API less confusing

note.body:
It's very often what some GTK+ 3 applications are used on KDE desktop or the opposite.

And for projects like chrome or firefox when they targeting linux dekstop and want to achieve visual integration with the environment it makes more sense to target all GTK-based desktops via GTK style context (even in that hackish way as they currently do that) instead of targeting only specific DEs like Cinnamon or GNOME.

And even in GNOME desktop itself some distributions like Ubuntu are shipping different GTK theme.

So your overall position on that leaving an impression what you want to deny the existance of any other GTK-based environments other than GNOME and any other GTK themes other than Adwaita.

> App developers target a single theme - Gnome apps target Gnome's theme, elementary apps target elementary's theme.

I am not aware of any major applications to proof your point -- most of the applications are targeting to integrate with either GTK, Qt or xrdb. Even kdelibs-based applications are following your common Qt appearance settings rather than targeting specifically default KDE theme.

> And theme authors usually target the desktop they're using - if they use Gnome apps, they do a Gnome theme, if they use KDE apps, they also/only do a KDE theme.

Most of the theme developers are targeting usually GTK+metacity+xfwm or so. I don't know any themes which are targeting only GTK+GNOME only (i would agree what regarding Qt and KDE situation is a bit different here since there are no many major Qt DEs right now.

> Obviously they would ship their own Firefox theme - if they used Firefox.

Could you elaborate more on why it is obvious?

>Plus, writing a spec is work. And creating a spec that actually makes sense is even more work. And nobody has shown any interest in doing that work either.

I think I have both experience and interest for coming up with such spec. But actually a minimal effort to get such spec would be at least to document the StyleContext of Adwaita theme and make that set of variables to be a defined standard.


(edits were done to fix the spacing between quotes and my replies to not break markdown parser)

events.target_title: Provide damned-lies in Docker

note.body:
Using Docker for development environments is pretty useful to prevent from having to install extra dependencies on the host system (like `libicu-dev` or `mariadb-devel` for instance).

Using this, any new developer will be able to run `damned-lies` without any understanding of system requirements, just like what Flatpak does. The process is a simple as running `docker-compose up` and getting into the code.

note.body:
the only thing that looks pretty strange to me is (from meson log):
```
Called `/home/pi/prod/9.2.0/pkg-config/bin/pkg-config --variable=includedir gio-unix-2.0` -> 0
/home/pi/prod/9.2.0/glib/include
Got pkgconfig variable includedir : /home/pi/prod/9.2.0/glib/include
```

if this is how meson determines path to gio-unix that is later used in the build - then this is wrong:
1) this is .pc file for gio-unix-2.0
```
pi@raspberrypi:~/prod/9.2.0/glib/lib/arm-linux-gnueabihf/pkgconfig $ more gio-unix-2.0.pc 
prefix=/home/pi/prod/9.2.0/glib
libdir=${prefix}/lib/arm-linux-gnueabihf
includedir=${prefix}/include

Name: GIO unix specific APIs
Description: unix specific headers for glib I/O library
Version: 2.62.0
Requires: gobject-2.0, gio-2.0
Cflags: -I${includedir}/gio-unix-2.0
```
2) this is where gio-unix-2.0 includes sit:
```
/home/pi/prod/9.2.0/glib/include/gio-unix-2.0
```
3) this is where gunixoutputstream.h sits:
```
pi@raspberrypi:~/prod/9.2.0/glib/include/gio-unix-2.0/gio $ ls -la
total 68
drwxr-xr-x 2 pi pi 4096 Sep 18 00:00 .
drwxr-xr-x 3 pi pi 4096 Aug 18 02:04 ..
-rw-r--r-- 1 pi pi 8679 Sep  5 18:56 gdesktopappinfo.h
-rw-r--r-- 1 pi pi 2218 Sep  5 18:56 gfiledescriptorbased.h
-rw-r--r-- 1 pi pi 5761 Sep  5 18:56 gunixconnection.h

-rw-r--r-- 1 pi pi 4245 Sep  5 18:56 gunixfdlist.h
-rw-r--r-- 1 pi pi 3767 Sep  5 18:56 gunixfdmessage.h
-rw-r--r-- 1 pi pi 3018 Sep  5 18:56 gunixinputstream.h
```

Firmware update doesn't work

note.body:
Had the same problem on my Lenovo. As it turns out, the button is a bit misleading. Because firmware updates are installed on reboot. So it should probably provide a "Update & reboot"-button instead of an "Update"-button.

The `fwupdmgr update` command asked for rebooting, so I guess that's something Gnome Software should also do and is a safe way make sure the update is installed. (We already do this for regular package managers like `dnf` or `apt` anyway, so why not for firmware, where it makes even more sense, as well?)

events.target_title: The Album View should display song numbers

note.body:
I agree that track numbers should be displayed.
It was the first thing I noticed when I started using Music and I keep missing them.

The idea that track numbers are not needed in album view assumes that the provided meta-data is always correct. This is far from the case a lot of times.

Call me old-fashioned, but I listen to music in an album orientated way. CDs and vinyls, at home or in my car, from song 1 to the last. Not having the numbers in front of the tracks in Music prevents me from:

1) Talk about track numbers when I do not know the track title. Not everywhere titles are displayed, available, relevant or possible to remember.

2) Confirm that track order is correct in case of identical, similar or missing track titles and act on it accordingly.

note.body:
The only thing that invites to be clicked in the "Albums" view is the cover art image, even though the artist and album name work as well. I suppose it has to do with the minimal border around the image that give it more the impression of a button.

Even the rows in the "Songs" view are not that inviting to be clicked to be honest. It's all for the lack of a more attractive option that one ends up doing it anyway.

I've seen players with actions buttons like "play" displayed for every item, as well as those that display it on hover. Where the first is overkill, the second hides it's functionality. So both of those are not really an option either if you ask me.

Simply adding (more distinct) column and row borders to give it more of a classic table layout might do the trick already, but this creates a more cluttered view again at the same time.

Sorry for not being more helpful in the "new ideas" department, but that's about it in terms of what comes to mind right away.

events.target_title: Screen recorder fails ("Cannot open output file") for filesystem which does not accept ":" in filenames
Screen recorder fails ("Cannot open output file") for filesystem which does not accept ":" in filenames

note.body:
@carlosg (close to) spot on!
The Videos folder is mapped to an NTFS drive, and NTFS does not like ":" in file names. I forgot all about that detail, sorry. The only reason I still have that is because I need to keep it for backup purposes, for the rest I never notice it.

That leaves me with two questions:
1. Should the recorder deal with the fact that some drive formats can't handle certain characters and either not use them or have a fall-back? (NTFS is unfortunately not that exotic)
2. Can I adapt the output file name format, simply using yyyyMMDDTHHMMSS, as a work-around?

events.target_title: Screen recorder fails ("Cannot open output file") for filesystem which does not accept ":" in filenames

note.body: Personally I'd say take the most (reasonable) restricted file system (FAT16, excluding illegal UNIX character?). Files are likely to be exchanged in the end and you never know where it will end up. This fixes the issue for the recorder for sure and will reduce the risk of issues when sending the files.

events.target_title: Inconsistent rules for shortcuts between different applications when switching keymaps

note.body:
I can confirm this issue as well.
Running Ubuntu 19.10 with Wayland. Switching to Xorg makes the issue go away.
I've lost work because of it a couple of times already so it is highly frustrating.

Setup:
- Default keyboard layout: AZERTY (French)
- Alternative layout: QWERTY (US int.)

Pressing CTRL+A with a French layout selects all text in applications like Firefox, RocketChat, Gedit or Geary.
Pressing CTRL+A with a US layout selects all text in applications like Firefox or RocketChat, but closes applications like Gedit or Geary, as Q is on the position of the A in the French layout.
The same thing happens with CTRL+W and CTRL+Z, for closing tabs in Firefox and undo.

You can imagine the dangers and frustration of closing applications or tabs by accident this way.

This used to be the behaviour for Xorg as well, but luckily it was fixed: https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=162726

Shortcuts should follow the layout of the active layout, in all applications, not stick to the default layout and inconsistently doing so.

The title of this bug should be changed to something like "Default keyboard layout used for shortcuts instead of active layout under Wayland" to correspond to the behaviour and make it easier to find.

events.target_title: Support VLAN configuration

note.body:
@bberg asked that I explain my usecase here.

In my office we have a number of VLANs configured (for example our CCTV cameras are on the same physical network, but we don't want most users being able to access them, so there only a few switch ports that allow users to tag their network traffic with the VLAN tag for CCTV), on my desk switch I can connect to a number of them if I tag the traffic for those VLANs, but to do that I need to configure the interface with a VLAN tag. 

Currently I have to launch nm-connection-editor if I want to be able to configure a network switch, but it doesn't make sense to me that this isn't part of the standard network setup. 

I get that most people won't use VLAN setup, as it is mainly an enterprise thing I guess. But for me I regularly use VLANs and I feel it should be in the same place as the rest of the network config

If any of that doesn't make sense, please feel free to let me know.

note.body: For better integration with environments other than GNOME.

events.target_title: Use GtkMenu instead GtkPopover outside GNOME

note.body:
>  I don't think that using menus instead of popovers improves integration, really.
>  And 'everybody but GNOME prefers menus over popovers' is a very unsubstantiated claim.

I use XFCE, MATE, sometimes LXDE. Sometimes XFCE uses popovers (as replacement of small dialogs, not menus). They don't use popovers in menu role. But they are based on GTK, which has its own non-modular file chooser, which uses popovers as menus.

I understand that you - GNOME developers - are volunteers and you don't have to test and use GTK in XFCE/MATE/something else than GNOME. But I'm using XFCE/MATE and I see some insonsistences between GTK and desktops other than GNOME.  I am contributing this merge request to improve consistence between context menus of file chooser and context menus of desktops other than GNOME.
In others words. GTK works and looks good in GNOME. But in other desktops only works good, not looks good (some parts of GTK). I'm adding this patch to correct appearance of file chooser outside GNOME.

> Hiding disabled menuitems makes the rest move around and is not always the best idea.

Maybe you are right. I will correct it when I will find time.

events.target_title: Use GtkMenu instead GtkPopover outside GNOME

note.body:
> "correct" is extremely subjective, but the other mistake here is thinking that `GtkFileChooser` is really something that can be fully integrated with other DEs... or _should_. IMO the real fix is looking to replace it with native choosers wherever possible, not trying in vain to make it look like everything else, which is a slippery slope that can never end.

@dboles. In my best dreams all current GTK dialogs are removed from GTK and moved to separate library called "libgnomedialogs". There is a separate library "libgtkdialogs" maintained with GTK which is a proxy between applications and dialogs implementation given by each GTK-based (or not GTK-based) desktop. In this case "libgnomedialogs" is an implementaion used by GNOME. This way we can avoid workarounds like "gtk-dialogs-use-header", widgets like GtkPlacesSidebar and forcing GNOME design principles in other GTK-based desktops. This way GNOME can better integrate dialogs with desktop (can you imagine Nautilus's context menu inside file chooser dialog list?)

But life is not my best dream. GTK is used in XFCE, LXDE, MATE, Cinnamon. GTK-based apps are used in KDE, Windows, Mac. Also GTK's file chooser is not modular. Any desktop can't affect its behavior and appearance. As long as GTK file chooser is not modular, it should be **NEUTRAL** as possible, not GNOME-like. Sorry, this is the reality. 

My merge request converts plain menu buttons/items to GMenu, which is good. Only other small change is that GtkMenu is used instead GtkPopover when "gtk-dialogs-user-header" is not enabled. This is dirty solution but it's simple and stable.

BTW My patch doesn't affect places view widget, you can remove its tag.

events.target_title: Use GtkMenu instead GtkPopover outside GNOME

note.body:
> Hiding disabled menuitems makes the rest move around and is not always the best idea

@matthiasc, fixed.

note.body:
@dboles 

> I still don't see any real rationable for why popovers are not "**NEUTRAL**"

Popovers *(in context menu role)* are used only in GNOME. Context menus based on GtkMenus are used in XFCE, LXDE, MATE, Cinnamon desktops. Also Windows, Mac and KDE desktop are using standard context menus instead boxes with big padding and small arrow. 
I have not any problem with popover as context menu. In GNOME. But in every other environment popover (or something like popover looks) is not used in context menu role.

> despite how loud you shout that word.

Sometimes I'm using uppercased letters for emphasis. Sorry for misunderstanding.

> you make a seemingly irrelevantly named setting would affect things other than what its name suggests

You're right. It's fixed now. I'm using XDG_CURRENT_DESKTOP env variable now.

> things will suddenly start looking very different, and not everyone may want that.

In GNOME context menus of GtkPlacesSidebar, GtkFileChooserWidget won't be changed. It will be looking the same.  In other environment it will be more native and good-looking.

---
I also prepared patch for Nautilus's places sidebar integration:
[nautilus-gmenu-places-sidebar.patch](/uploads/2ca4e0a924da69a3638c2d1defb12a57/nautilus-gmenu-places-sidebar.patch)

events.target_title: gnome-shell runs out of dbus match rules on the system bus
gnome-shell runs out of dbus match rules on the system bus

note.body: The `forecasts` list in WeatherSection::_getSummaryText() contains 95 items, which matches the number of dbus match rules added every time the menu is opened. This would suggest that whatever is causing this "leak" of dbus match rules is related to the forecasts.

events.target_title: gnome-shell runs out of dbus match rules on the system bus

note.body:
This is (at least partly) a libgweather issue. The YRNO plugin creates a new GWeatherInfo for each forecast entry in parse_forecast_xml_new() and each GWeatherInfo has its own GSettings object. The GSettings object is never freed in GWeatherInfo dispose/finalize, leading to this leak. After adding a `g_clear_object (&priv->settings)` to dispose, I can now see the matches being removed in the dbus monitor after I manually trigger garbage collection. I've not yet seen them being removed automatically without manually triggering gc, so there might be another issue on the gnome-shell/gjs side. Due to this it is still possible to run into the original error message by opening and closing the date menu a few times.

I will open a new issue against libgweather about the GSettings leak and leave this issue open to track the gc side of the problem.

However there are some plans to move this functionality to gnome-shell: gnome-shell#155. I think this issue can be marked as a duplicate of the gnome-shell issue. Installing evolution should work around the issue in the meantime.

events.target_title: Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body: @vain If you do file an issue for HarfBuzz, could you, please, post a link to it here as a reference? I would love for HarfBuzz to support BDF, PCF and Type1 fonts or at least to know the reasons why it doesn't.

events.target_title: Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body:
> A while back we had same discussion about Type1. I asked if Adobe wants to contribute that to HarfBuzz (Adobe is a major HarfBuzz contributor). I was told by Adobe that even their own apps are dropping support for Type1.

Perhaps this is the right thing to do, but unless we know the specific reasons why, we won't be able to evaluate it. “It's an old format” or “Adobe's doing it” alone just won't do ;} (it's a friendly smile, to be sure). We still have quite a sizeable, professional font selection available as Type 1. Granted: many of these are becoming/are available as OpenType, but some are not. Potential conversion is an option, but it places a burden on the user and, often, it may be not a trivial thing to do. On the other hand, there is a possibility to support Type 1 as a format. It would mean some work, perhaps even too much, but then _that_ would make a good argument.

> So here we are 17 years later still having the same argument.

And yet for the 17 years (and counting) BDFs proved to be working fine…

What would be a benefit from converting them to the newer format? “Less code” would be one, but, again, that would “cost” the users and could lead to an “automatic converter” which would, effectively, make “more code”, but this time “not mine” code ;}.

What I would try to argue, if I was in your place, is not that the argument is the same, but that the context has changed. Is the need for support the old formats still high enough to justify the effort to implement it or not? Now, that could be a valid argument if you'd be able to evaluate it properly.

I, for one, like my bitmap Terminus font and I want to use it. Could I live without it? Yes. At a cost of somewhat unappreciated disruption, but yes. What I cannot suffer is:

> Just convert.

With no good reason?… :}

> The world has to move on.

Beware of progress for the sake of progress :}

events.target_title: Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body:
An excellent guide!

Incidentally, it illustrates the “burden” placed on the user, I was talking about earlier :}

events.target_title: Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body: No

events.target_title: Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body:
> I'm honestly curious, who is "we"

We… are Venom, of course… ;}. On a more serious note though, we as in everyone.

> and where is that collection?

One place would be [CTAN](https://ctan.org/topic/font-type1). Other, would be old type collections like Adobe Font Folio 9 and earlier. The latter may not be publicly accessible on the internet, but I'd bet they're still there in an occasional drawer or two and still are worth grabbing for some quality Caslon, Gill, Bookman, Bodoni, Baskerville or Garamond.

I do realize contemporary “desktop” fonts are available in abundance and in OpenType, but if you're a print designer you may appreciate continuous support for “legacy” font formats.

I think that's at least worth considering.

> And for what's it worth, the OpenType CFF (.otf) format is essentially Type 1 in a different container.

True. In that case, either an automated converter or outright format support shouldn't be much a problem, assuming sizeable portion of the handling code is already there.

> The reasons are stated in his blog post and they are good :)

If you mean [https://blogs.gnome.org/mclasen/2019/05/25/pango-future-directions/](https://blogs.gnome.org/mclasen/2019/05/25/pango-future-directions/), then they are reasons for Pango hopping from FreeType to HarfBuzz. They are good, but only by implication related to dropping support for Type 1 and bitmap fonts.

Now, these are good reasons to drop support for Type 1: [https://blog.typekit.com/2005/10/06/phasing_out_typ/](https://blog.typekit.com/2005/10/06/phasing_out_typ/) (this and incentive to sell some new old fonts, but it doesn't invalidate the premise ;}). Notice, however, that what happened was a kind of “gentle” phasing out, not whack-bam-bang-dead sudden solution ;}. I don't think the latter was intended and I'm not here to pass the blame (that would be pointless), but it jolts you when before *minor* update your terminal works fine and after it spews some garbled mess.

This could also be a hint in this discussion [https://indesignsecrets.com/poll-results-do-you-still-use-classic-postscript-type-1-fonts.php](https://indesignsecrets.com/poll-results-do-you-still-use-classic-postscript-type-1-fonts.php). Unfortunately, no information is given as to the population size and composition.

> Remember that those who do the actual (maintenance) work on the code get to decide what happens and what doesn't :).

I'm pretty sure I have that in mind ;}

events.target_title: Gnome cheats in fullscreen benchmarks (gives smaller than requested window)

note.body:
Mutter fullscreening is broken also with the common open source benchmark called "glmark2".

Try for example:
```
apt install glmark2
for i in $(seq 10); do glmark2 --fullscreen; done
```

And exit glmark2 windows with ESC key as they come up.

Only first run (cold start) gets fullscreen, rest of the runs (warm start = faster), are windowed.  This is timing related issue, because if I slow down glmark2 by prefixing it with `strace -f -o /dev/null`, most of the times the glmark2 window comes up as fullscreen, as expected.

This was tested on BDW and KBL HW with Ubuntu 16.04 & and 18.04-pre, both having latest updates as of today.  I.e. similarly to GfxBench fullscreen issue, this isn't recent regression, Mutter has been broken for a long time.

Fullscreen works always in the other Linux desktops that I tried, it's buggy only in Gnome.

events.target_title: Gnome cheats in fullscreen benchmarks (gives smaller than requested window)

note.body:
Gnome flashback with Metacity doesn't have this particular problem, but it has other problems (fullscreen fails in GpuTest tests, and its performance is bad).  Gnome flashback with compiz (in Ubuntu) doesn't have this problem either.  XFCE, KDE & Unity work fine, mutter / gnome-shell is the only windowing manager which has broken fullscreen handling.

Problem is still there with newer mutter / gnome-shell v3.28.1 (Ubuntu 18.04) and v3.28.2 (ClearLinux).

It happens also with Wayland version when the benchmark gets run through XWayland.

I am interested in this task, as I love writing parsers. Before I start, I have some questions:

In your presentation "Replacing C library code with Rust" you mentioned using parser generators like `lalrpop`. Is it planned to replace the hand written parsers with that? I just ask before I rewrite one of several parsers with a hand-rolled lexer.

If we go for writing our own, would you split lexer and parser, i.e. move the lexer to its own class (in the same file or not)? Would you lex first and then consume the tokens (save them in a vec) or would you lex on the fly, the pace controlled by the parser?

events.target_title: Hash sum mismatch while trying to install Lollypop
Duplex scanning

note.body:
Thanks to this clue, I found the hard-to-discover feature.

This feature isn't dead simple to understand, either.

I think that this would be better accomplished by a new scanning instruction: all page backs from feeder.
It would interleave the result into the existing document in the obvious way.

I'm pretty sure that this would be a lot clearer to ordinary users.  It matches what they think they are doing.

One step further would be to add a scan command "all page fronts from feeder" and replace "all pages from feeder" with "both sides from feeder".  The "preferences: scan sides" should then be eliminated.  I think that this would be another move towards simplicity.

It would be good to grey-out those "from feeder" scan commands not supported by the selected device.  They are just confusing and misleading cues.  Even though a scanner that can scan both sides could scan "all page backs from feeder", it is probably also a trap for users so it should be greyed-out too ("all page fronts" would be useful though).

If all these are accepted, I think that the "reorder pages" could be eliminated or perhaps simplified to just "reverse pages".  The other transformations don't seem that useful.

There is one case that isn't handled well by this new interface: if the ADR doesn't work perfectly.  For example, if two pages were fed as one (skipping a page) or if a feed failure caused a scan to stop prematurely.  It must be possible to resume an "all page backs" scan from where it left off.  Bonus: warn the user if the count of fronts and backs doesn't match.

events.target_title: Memory leak

note.body:
garbage collection does ring a bell for me: In maxima (which is programmed in lisp and therefore uses garbage collection) one thing I have encountered quite frequently is Memory fragmentation.

One case was: 
* We read in a line from a csv file (which allocates memory for the string), 
* interpret it (storing the temporary result in memory)
* add the result to the list we read the file into.
* then we repeat this process.

As soon as the available memory is used up we call the garbage collector (constantly calling the garbage collector makes the program slow.) => All the strings and temporary results are freed. But as the list with the results is scattered all over the memory the address the heap ends doesn't change by freeing the memory and even if most of the memory is free there still is no single memory region that can store more than a line of text.
 
Also a small memory leak that occurs only infrequently can quickly eat up all of the system's memory. A generic scheme for doing so would be:
* Leak one byte of memory every 10 seconds
* and from time to time allocate 100 kilobytes for a bitmap that is only used tmporarily and will be freed at the next garbage collector run.

If you allocate a bitmap every ten seconds the memory layout quickly is
* leaked byte
* 100 kilobytes of bitmap
* leaked byte
* 100 kilobytes of bitmap
...

After calling the garbage collector it reads:
* leaked byte
* 100 kilobytes of free memory
* leaked byte
* 100 kilobytes of free memory

Leaking the next byte will lead to:

* leaked byte
* leaked byte
* 100 kilobytes minus 1 byte of free memory
* leaked byte
* 100 kilobytes of free memory

The next bitmap won't fit into the first free memory slot any more.

The question therefore might be: Does gnome-shell constantly use more memory or does it just reduce the amount of continuous space that is available in memory?
Does gnome-shell provide way to measure the amount of memory that actually contains data? (One approximate way would perhaps be to zero all memory that is freed and counting the number of zeroes).

events.target_title: Memory leak

note.body:
>  GNOME Shell consumes ~70MB right after starting up;
>
>- Jumps to ~95MB after opening the aggregate menu popup;
>
>- Jumps to ~250MB after loading the icon grid (with ~90 icons);
>
>- **This might be a good target for future investigation**;

If valgrind doesn't find a leak I have a theory - that still needs to be verified by actually looking at the code:
* gnome-shell allocates memory for loading a compressed bitmap
* gnome-shell uncompresses the bitmap (which involves allocating memory for the uncompressed bitmap)
* gnome-shell creates a thumbnail (which involves allocating memory for the thumbnail
* This process now is repeated for about 90 thumbnails => Memory usage of about 250 Megabytes
Afterwards the garbage-collector is called, which frees about 180 small non-contiguous memory regions in the middle of the heap. Which doesn't allow to free any of the system's memody => big memory fragmentation.

In this case it would be better to 
* allocate two memory chunks: One big enough for the biggest compressed image and one big enough for the biggest uncompressed one
* Creating all the bitmaps re-using the two memory chunks every time
* and then calling the garbage-collector.

There will be still a big block [sized one compressed and one uncompressed image] in the middle of the heap after that that cannot be un-claimed by gnome-shell. But there won't be an individual hole in the heap for each individual image after that.

events.target_title: Memory leak

note.body:
If my guess is right the only way to make a list of thumbnails without fragmenting the memory would be:

1. Make the list
2. Allocate the memory for the thumbnails (their size is know in advance)
3. Actually make the thumbnails
4. (optionally): Invoke the garbage collector.

This way the garbage collector will free all the memory used by the compressed and uncompressed bitmaps without leaving big holes in the heap that cannot be reclaimed by the system for other tasks than gnome-shell.

Memory leak

note.body: Ok... ..the new issue is #137. But as one of the things that seems to make gnome-shell grow by a few kilobytes to a Megabyte every second is window thumbnails I guess what I wrote might be relevant here, too - in case that I have guessed right which approach is used for creating the thumbnails.

events.target_title: Memory leak

note.body:
A few lisps allow trade-offs between running the garbage-collector all the time (which consumes much time) and seldom (which consumes much memory). If you run such a lisp (for example gcl) at the same time as firefox the result will be loads of disk activity and a very slow system. Why I don't know, though.

Not that the gnome-shell only starts running the garbage collector if the system is really running out of memory. On my Ubuntu Box the system will start killing processes without the gnome-shell getting smaller. But I guess if a process tries to allocate a big chunk of memory gnome-shell won't be able to react and run the garbage collector in time before the system kills a process (in my case sadly wayland).

GtkEntryCompletion and GtkComboBox only show top level nodes when using GtkTreeModelFilter
GtkEntryCompletion and GtkComboBox only show top level nodes when using GtkTreeModelFilter

note.body:
Ok, so here is a minimal example. When typing in the entry on the bottom, the completion will only show the top level nodes, but the treeview will show all nodes.

```
#!/usr/bin/env python

import gi
gi.require_version('Gtk', '3.0')
from gi.repository import Gtk
import os, sys


class GUI (Gtk.Window):
	def __init__(self):

		Gtk.Window.__init__(self)
		self.set_size_request(300, 300)
		self.connect('destroy', self.on_window_destroy)
		self.filter_text = ''
		box = Gtk.Box(orientation = Gtk.Orientation.VERTICAL)
		self.store = Gtk.TreeStore(str)
		filter_store = self.store.filter_new()
		filter_store.set_visible_func(self.visible_func)
		sw = Gtk.ScrolledWindow()
		treeview = Gtk.TreeView()
		sw.add(treeview)
		box.pack_start(sw, True, True, 0)
		renderer = Gtk.CellRendererText()
		column = Gtk.TreeViewColumn("Filtered Column", renderer, text=0)
		treeview.append_column(column)
		treeview.set_model(filter_store)
		combo = Gtk.ComboBox.new_with_model_and_entry(self.store)
		combo.set_entry_text_column(0)
		entry = combo.get_child()
		entry.connect("changed", self.entry_changed, filter_store)
		completion = Gtk.EntryCompletion()
		completion.set_model(self.store)
		entry.set_completion(completion)
		renderer_text = Gtk.CellRendererText()
		completion.pack_start(renderer_text, True)
		completion.add_attribute(renderer_text, "text", 0)
		completion.set_match_func(self.match_func)
		box.pack_start(combo, False, False, 0)
		self.add(box)
		for i in range(10, 20):
			p = self.store.append(None, [str(i)])
			for d in range(10, 20):
				pp = self.store.append(p, [str(i * d)])
				for e in range(10, 20):
					self.store.append(pp, [str(i * d * e)])
		self.show_all()

	def entry_changed (self, entry, filter_store):
		self.filter_text = entry.get_text()
		filter_store.refilter()

	def match_func (self, completion, key, iter_):
		if key in self.store[iter_][0]:
			return True
		return False

	def visible_func (self, model, iter_, data):
		if self.filter_text in model[iter_][0]:
			return True
		return False

	def on_window_destroy(self, window):
		Gtk.main_quit()

def main():
	app = GUI()
	Gtk.main()
		
if __name__ == "__main__":
	sys.exit(main())
```

events.target_title: GtkEntryCompletion and GtkComboBox only show top level nodes when using GtkTreeModelFilter

note.body:
Ok, so I ran your example code, and I see you turned a tree structure to a flat list. After thinking about this a while, I believe I see why Gtk did it this way, because there is no way to display all tree elements at the same time without using a flat list.

I had thought about using mouse/keyboard focus to show the child nodes of a tree structure, but that defeats the simplicity of a completion. 

Thanks for the answer with a good illustration app.

Get attributes of GtkTreeViewColumn
Get attributes of GtkTreeViewColumn

note.body:
I got it. This can be done with ```gtk_cell_area_attribute_get_column ()```

Example in Python:

```
for column in treeview.get_columns():
    if column.get_visible():
        cell_area = column.get_area()
        renderer = cell_area.get_cells()[0]
        print(cell_area.attribute_get_column(renderer, "text"))
```

events.target_title: Add in-app player

note.body:
Two feature requests/hopes for the built in player:

- If it is able to automatically play the next episode, then it should be able to do so in ascending order as well as descending order. A news podcast should play the next most recent episode after the episode just finished.
- It would be nice to have control over the gstreamer pipeline in the preferences, the music player Quod Libet has this feature and I love it as I can pipe the audio to my jack server to route how I see fit.

events.target_title: Add in-app player

note.body:
Gstreamer is very flexible, it can be configured to route output pretty much anywhere you'd like, from a file on disk to PulseAudio. Here's a [tutorial on building pipelines in C](https://gstreamer.freedesktop.org/documentation/tutorials/basic/dynamic-pipelines.html).

Basically you chain a bunch of elements together to define a processing pipeline that the data should flow through. I believe that by default the output/sink pipeline would normally consist of one element:

```
data.sink = gst_element_factory_make ("autoaudiosink", "sink");
```

But Quod Libet lets users customise this by accepting the same text based format that the `gst-launch` command does. Instead of using the `autoaudiosink`, I configure it like so:

```
jackaudiosink client-name=quodlibet port-pattern=REAPER
```

I think this is the [relevant code](https://github.com/quodlibet/quodlibet/blob/2b38182061ac37371f67148afd7d0b930eba0514/quodlibet/quodlibet/player/gstbe/util.py#L107) in their repository.

Suspend timer should be reset when inhibitor lifts

note.body:
I have the same experience when playing TV series. Once the episode is over (the movie player stops playing), the display immediately starts to dim and in a few seconds the screen is locked. If I don't get up from the couch fast enough, I have to unlock the screen every time just to play the next episode.

With suspend enabled by default now, this will not only lock my screen, but also autosuspend immediately after playing the episode. It's even worse than screenlock, because the screen doesn't dim gradually, providing some time to react - the system suspends immediately.

It doesn't make sense to kick in power management functions right after the idle inhibitor was lifted. Instead, the timer should be reset and counted from zero.

My experience with playing movies is from Fedora 27 (gnome 3.26.2). Frantisek's experience with LiveCD suspending immediately after finishing the installation is from Fedora 28 (gnome 3.27.92).

events.target_title: Suspend timer should be reset when inhibitor lifts

note.body: I've tested movie playback in Totem and Youtube playback in Firefox on Fedora 28 (gnome 3.27.92). In both cases, if the movie is longer than the suspend timeout, the system auto-suspends immediately after the video finishes.

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
Hi Carlos and others, just a quick thought. While it's true that software mostly doesn't come in tarballs nowadays, there's one notable exception - gaming. Non-steam sites like GOG or Humble provide bash installers for their games, because it's the most universal option. I'm worried that if that can't be executed easily (yeah, I know about the executable bit, but that's still in GUI), they'll resort to deb packages instead (they officially support just Ubuntu anyway), and that will only harm Linux ecosystem. I don't think they'll adopt Flatpak yet, because it's a) still too experimental and unfinished b) can't be completely self-contained, but requires a repo with runtime for installation (so offline install is not possible, and when the repo/runtime is gone in a few years, the installation won't work; which goes against DRM-free principles at least GOG is based on). 

Perhaps this Nautilus change could be done in a few years when we have Flatpak (or alternatives) fully functional and polished? Food for thought :) Thanks.

events.target_title: Solution for Type=Link .desktop files?

note.body:
I've just arrived to report a bug that all my .desktop files with type=link stopped working (and I have a lot of them) and found this report. Is it true that this is not a bug but the support was removed intentionally? What is the rationale behind this? I can't comprehend why you would remove support for a freedesktop standard that is very much targeted to be used from a file browser (because you store shortcut as a file). It's the same use case as for windows' [lnk files](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortcut_(computing)#Microsoft_Windows) that are used as a shortcut e.g. for opening up a web page. Software and game vendors often include such links in program directories.

I have many such shortcuts stored in a single bookmarked folder, many of them pointing to remote machines (ssh, ftp, etc), when I want to connect to them from a file manager. I also use these files when I want to save a link to a web page alongside certain files, a simple drag&drop from Firefox's address bar creates them. All of this is very useful and can't be replaced by a Nautilus side bar. It's an interoperability standard. You can open an URI by an application of choice, instead of relying on a bookmark system in a selected application. You shortcuts can stay local to a group of files. Please don't remove support for interoperability standards?

events.target_title: Solution for Type=Link .desktop files?

note.body:
Hi Carlos, I'm using `nautilus-3.28.1-1.fc28.x86_64` and the error message is exactly the same as in this bug's description. 

I can put remote machines links into Nautilus side bar, but I don't like it for several reasons:  
a) If you have many of them, it's a visual noise and clutters the application  
b) You can't organize them in any hierarchical structure  
c) You can't edit them  
d) You can't access them from a different application or from a terminal  
e) You can't synchronize the links between computers (definitely not as easily as a folder synchronization)

I'm not saying Nautilus side bar is not useful, it's just that I personally consider a folder with link files a superior approach (of course, one has to write the desktop files by hand, so it's definitely not a user-friendly system, just for power users). If I have no other chance, I'll convert them to Nautilus links anyway, but I'm feeling sad about it. Files are awesome and allow flexibility that applications don't.

I agree the spec is mostly written for menus. The type=application files are not much useful from a file manager, because they don't allow to work with relative paths. But the type=link files I always considered closer to a free alternative to microsoft's .lnk files, which are often executed from a file explorer. Maybe it's just my impression.

The http:// links stored in folders were I think nicely covered in [this comment](#note_231694). It's quite often handy to save a web link to a bunch of local files, be in related to a particular bug report, a development project, art files, a (course) book, tax reports, game files, or really whatever. Any time you have some files on your disk that you store long-term and want to mark down where they came from, or link to some guide how to work with them, or something similar, you can either create an `info.txt` file and paste that URL into it (and then always open it, and copy&paste it to the browser), or simply drag&drop the URL from your browser to Nautilus (which even puts the title as the file name, so you easily see what it is) and then double click that file. The former is tedious, while the latter is much more convenient, and that's why I often use(d) it.

events.target_title: Solution for Type=Link .desktop files?

note.body:
File managers are supposed to perform file operations, including opening a file, which means executing an application and passing that file as an argument. If nautilus can launch gedit or any other application of user choice when double clicking a txt file, I can't understand why it shouldn't launch the corresponding application when double clicking a type=link desktop file. It's just another type of a file that is *supposed to be opened*. It doesn't make sense to move all your e.g. documents to an app like gnome-documents and open them from there. It often make sense to open the files locally, from a particular directory. The same logic applies for desktop files, be it type=application or type=link. Sometimes you don't want to move them to a system app launcher or a bookmark in a particular application, but launch them from a particular directory. Removing support for launching desktop files is analogous to removing support launching exe and lnk files on Windows. I can imagine something like that driven by security concerns, but it's duct-taping over a problem instead of solving the root cause (which is already being worked on by flatpak/snap and sandboxing). Especially for type=link files, I don't see any possible security issue at all, it's just saying "open this URI". It's very much like saying "open this text/html file". You just run xdg-open on it.

If you're determined that desktop files support must die in Nautilus, I don't think you should replace a well-defined and widely-supported standard with some custom solution like the html snippet above, that tries to guess the user intentions. (At best, you could create a text file with the dropped content, if a text string is dragged to Nautilus, that might be reasonable). I don't think this improves the experience the users get, though.

events.target_title: Define G_MSVC_SYMBOL_PREFIX correctly for ARM

note.body:
x86 is the architecture, where G_MSVC_SYMBOL_PREFIX needs to be defined as "_". In the other, majority of cases (_WIN64, _M_ARM, _M_ARM64), it needs to be defined as "".  
This was the reason to have the condition like this (and not the other way round):

`#ifdef _M_IX86`  
`#define G_MSVC_SYMBOL_PREFIX "_"`  
`#else`  
`#define G_MSVC_SYMBOL_PREFIX ""`  
`#endif`

events.target_title: Cannot make modal popover appear by clicking an entry icon within a CellRendererText

note.body: It may be that there is a different way of doing it, but the basic goal seems reasonable enough: have a date field where the user can either enter a date string with the keyboard or use a calendar popover. It works fine with a plain Entry widget, but for uniformity in my GUI I want to have it work the same way when editing tables.

events.target_title: Cannot make modal popover appear by clicking an entry icon within a CellRendererText

note.body:
I tracked the "destroy" signal on the Entry; it gets deallocated with the TreeView. However the "unmap" signal on the Entry is getting triggered as soon as the popover activates.

(As a side note, it would be helpful if the lifecycle of the Editable widgets was documented so that you could see when they are available, and also how persistent any changes are going to be).

events.target_title: Cannot make modal popover appear by clicking an entry icon within a CellRendererText

note.body: I've been dusting off my old C debugging skills (its been a couple of decades). It seems that gtk_popover_apply_modality() is being called recursively. The second time it gets called with modal=0, leading to a call to _gtk_popover_parent_hierarchy_changed(), which contains the offending modification of priv->window. Full call stack attached.[debug2.txt](/uploads/d92b24c42325c0b0bc5280c6a3b9c82b/debug2.txt)

events.target_title: Cannot make modal popover appear by clicking an entry icon within a CellRendererText

note.body:
My bad. There is a recursive call with modal=False (see traceback lines 1 and 42 in the attachment), but its not the source of the problem. As you say, the root cause seems to be that the Editable is removed from the TreeView once it loses focus, becoming orphaned and hence presumably not having a window. This is propagated to child widgets, including the Popover.

I presume that fixing this would mean keeping the Editable attached to the TreeView but unmapped.

For my application the workaround is going to be attaching the Popover to the TreeView widget and using the gtk_popover_set_pointing_to() call to locate it in the right place.

[debug3.txt](/uploads/ac9e97de09e8b70fc6b5583beed829d7/debug3.txt)

events.target_title: Cannot make modal popover appear by clicking an entry icon within a CellRendererText

note.body: Thanks for helping me look in to this. I'll close this, and post a bug report on the documentation asking if the lifecycle of the editables can be documented.

note.body:
```
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10692]: (EE)
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10692]: Fatal server error:
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10692]: (EE) failed to read Wayland events: Broken pipe
org.gnome.Shell.desktop[10692]: (EE)
```
i.e. `strerror` is "Broken Pipe"


    /hw/xwayland/xwayland.c:
    xwl_read_events (struct xwl_screen *xwl_screen)
    {
    …
    ret = wl_display_read_events(xwl_screen->display);
    if (ret == -1)
        FatalError("failed to read Wayland events: %s\n", strerror(errno));

Can this error be handled gracefully in the Shell/Mutter or has the underlying problem that these even show up be fixed?

events.target_title: GtkFileChooser: button create folder not correctly labelled for accessiblity
When I press down arrow, evince cycles on the same line
When I press down arrow, evince cycles on the same line
Re-introduce caret/cursor width configuration option

note.body:
Hello,

Sorry for the delay, I've not received e-mail notifications.

The best way should be to have a gsettings, on Windows, there is a simple interface where the user can change the caret size.

We should make it possible to configure it. If you don't accept to make it possible with gsettings, we should let it on the CSS part and the user could create a theme to only change the caret size, for example with the tool called Oomox.

I don't think changing the cursor size by default is needed for the High Contrast users.

Best regards,
Alex.

displays start of line on braille when backspacing text at end of long line

note.body:
@joanmarie OK, we'll investigate. It's really difficult for us to find a concrete scenario reproducible for us. We've different behavior on different machines.

We're continuing to investigate and come back here to report our progress.

Best regards,
Alex.

events.target_title: Make double-orca presses perform the underlying key action

note.body:
Le 28/06/2018 à 15:10, Joanmarie Diggs a écrit :> If this merge request is just a patch for people to try rather than 
> something you actually expect me to merge, please find a different way 
> to make such things available. If I misunderstood you, my apologies. 
> Otherwise, please close this. Thanks!
> 

You're completely correct and I'm agree with you. We've think the patch would be useful for people would need this feature without having latest AT-SPI, it's for example the case of one of the Hypra users but right it's not intended to be merged.

Thanks in advance.

Best regards,
Alex.

note.body:
### Food (prices taken from Safeway)
* Hot dogs (2x24ct) = $11
* Hamburgers (150 at $1/patty frozen or not) = $150
* Veggie burgers (forgot to price this, guess 25 ct) = $25 
* Buns: hot dog (6x8ct) + hamburger (18x8ct) = $32
* Potatoes: Chips (6 bags) + potato salad (4x3lb tub) = $48
* Condiments: ketchup (2 big things), mustard (3 med sized yellow), lettuce (2 heads), tomato (5lb roma), onion (4lb), pickle slices (2 jars), relish (2 jars), cheese (14x10ct) = $84
* Tax: $30
* Rough estimate of $380 for all of this

### Drinks
* Jugs of water (grocery store)
* Do people want tea? soda? 
* Is alcohol an option?
* Rough estimate (assuming just jugs of water and some (6ish) 2L of soda) of $30

### Eating ware
* We should recycle as much as possible. I have amazon prime and am happy to have these items shipped to me (all items are prime eligible) and bring them to Denver.
* [recyclable plates, 125 ct](https://www.amazon.com/COUNT-Round-Disposable-Plates-product/dp/B06WW4FVMJ/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1534538643&sr=8-5&keywords=recyclable+plates) = $16
* [recyclable cutlery, 100 forks 50 spoons 50 knives](https://www.amazon.com/Disposable-Compostable-Biodegradable-Recyclable-Eco-Friendly/dp/B01MU1DF2R/ref=sr_1_11?s=home-garden&ie=UTF8&qid=1534538777&sr=1-11&keywords=recyclable+cutlery) = $18
* [recyclable cups, 2 packs of 50 ct](https://www.amazon.com/Repurpose-Compostable-Plant-Based-Clear-12-ounce/dp/B00NNR3S3S/ref=sr_1_4?s=home-garden&ie=UTF8&qid=1534539035&sr=1-4&keywords=recyclable%2Bcups&th=1) = $20
* [recyclable napkins, 500 ct](https://www.amazon.com/Seventh-Generation-Recycled-Unbleached-Napkins/dp/B00YPP14GU/ref=sr_1_4?ie=UTF8&qid=1534539117&sr=1-4&keywords=recyclable+napkins) = $10
* Total eating ware costs: $65

### Cornhole rental
https://www.capncornhole.com/rentals
* $59 for the weekend (Fri - Sun) or $39 for one day. These prices are with pick up and drop off in Castle Rock (It's on my way.)
* They would deliver and pick up at Denver for an extra $49 for each trip which doesn't seem worth it.
* My suggestion is for me to go pick it up Sunday morning and drop it off on my way home Sunday late afternoon/evening.
* Total games total: $40

Total sum estimate: $515

events.target_title: Deadlock after connecting a Thunderbolt3 docking station

note.body:
Ok so I ran bisect on the source and the offending commit is this one: Each revision after this cause mutter to deadlock when started on my XPS 13 with TB16 (with a 4k monitor over DP).

    cc4e0071489e739597a64ea2549ee9ab75060531 is the first bad commit
    commit cc4e0071489e739597a64ea2549ee9ab75060531
    Author: Daniel Stone <daniels@collabora.com>
    Date:   Thu Aug 3 15:42:50 2017 +0100

    renderer/native: Create GBM surfaces with modifiers

    Now that we have the list of supported modifiers from the monitor
    manager (via the CRTCs to the primary planes), we can use this to inform
    EGL it can use those modifiers to allocate the GBM surface with. Doing
    so allows us to use tiling and compression for our scanout surfaces.

    This requires the Mesa commit in:
    Mesa 10.3 (08264e5dad4df448e7718e782ad9077902089a07) or
    Mesa 10.2.7 (55d28925e6109a4afd61f109e845a8a51bd17652).
    Otherwise Mesa closes the fd behind our back and re-importing will fail.
    See FDO bug #76188 for details.

    https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=785779

events.target_title: Memory leak

note.body:
I guess it's worth noting and related to this: notifications and "now playing" media information over MPRIS leak quite a lot of memory. 
See bugs #139 and #138. If you're using Spotify with notifications turned on, you can leak hundreds of MB of memory each day.

events.target_title: One screen stays black in mutter when using modifiers

note.body:
I have tested mutter-3.28.0-1.2test.fc28.src.rpm provided by Olivier (thanks, especially for building it for us). However, it makes everything much worse for me.

On bootup, there's about a 10s delay between plymouth quitting and GDM showing anything (kernel log is displayed instead). GDM is then mirrored to all three screens (without scaling - it doesn't fit to the fullHD screens at all). After logging in, mirroring stays and the session is (likely) Xorg and every opened app stays full black. Shell crashes after a while. On a second attempt, there was no Xorg session in GDM (which I assume means Xorg is the default then). However, it seems GDM itself ran under Wayland (there was a Xwayland process belonging to the gdm user)

edit: this is on a WD15 (USB-C, not Thunderbolt) dock with 3200x1800 laptop screen and 2 external 1920x1080 screens.

Another edit: the black windows in the X session are most likely caused because I have enabled the Xorg 1.20 testing repo from ajax.

events.target_title: gnome-shell does not show search results nautilus does

note.body:
This issue is still a problem for me. I notice that the "Needs information" label was added and this was probably closed a while after that because no information was given, but no question seems to have been asked of the original author, which had the last reply.

In any case, there are some things that seem to reproduce quite quickly for me, I'll list them below. I can create a new ticket if desired.

All examples below are performed in the `~/Documents` folder and verified to be present in the Tracker index.

## Files Starting With Numbers
Filenames starting with a number, such as `2Blah.desktop` are shown in the Nautilus search, but not in the GNOME shell search using nautilus' search provider. Removing the number makes everything work correctly.

## Single-Character Words
Searching for multiple words in a filename, where one of these words consists of a single letter, is a problem. A filename such as `Blah B - Test 3.desktop` cannot be found from the GNOME shell search by typing `Blah B`. It _can_ be found via nautilus' search just fine, however.

Note that the file `Blah Bo - Test 4.desktop`, on the other hand, works fine. It seems to me it has something to do with the second word being a single character.

## The Word `Without` Is Magic
Is the word `Without` perhaps a keyword? A filename such as `Blah - Without.desktop` cannot be found by typing `Without`in GNOME shell's search (in fact, no files can, apparently). This works fine in nautilus' search. Changing the name to `Withou` and searching for `Withou` makes it magically work.

## Folder Paths Ignored
Folder paths are not considered for a search, for example, if I have the following hierarchy:

* MyFolder
    * My test 1
    * My test 2
    * My test 3 in MyFolder

Searching for `MyFolder` and nautilus in the dash will now show results one and four, but not two and three.

This may be intended behavior, however, since the behavior is at least consistent between the nautilus internal search and the search provider from the shell.

Perhaps it's just me, but I for some reason expected all these results to be shown in the GNOME shell search because in this case `MyFolder` operates more as a "tag", I don't just want to see a folder with that name, I wanted to see all items in that folder as well.

I understand this may be unrealistic as a folder is not a file and this may result in a lot of useless results being shown if their parent happened to have the name you're searching for. Perhaps proper file tagging may provide a better alternative to searching the full path.

When Night Light is activated, it should always show up in the user menu

events.target_title: Sync to the hardware refresh rate, not just 60.00Hz [performance]

note.body: Just to make sure, this merge request should also help with 4K displays running at 30Hz? I see a lot of posts talking about 144Hz displays mixed with 60 Hz, but not the reverse (slower refresh rates). I use a Dell XPS 13 with a HiDPI screen running at 60 Hz, but if I connect a 4K screen (HDMI 1.2) that refreshes at 30 Hz, even the laptop screen becomes sluggish. It does not happen in Windows or if I lower the resolution of the external monitor to make sure it runs at 60 Hz.

events.target_title: Accessibility

note.body:
The Accessibility developers has been working hard with the support and collaboration of their users over the past year.

An experimental Chrome/Chromium support has been started in Orca in version 3.32 and work kept in progress in version 3.34. We hope that soon it will be ready for end-user testing. In order to make this happen, ATK support in Chromium has been heavily improved.

Because there was no attribute included to identify that the ATK_ROLE_SECTION is an insertion or deletion and in order to be consistent with what has been done for other elements which have corresponding ARIA roles, two new roles ATK_ROLE_CONTENT_INSERTION and ATK_ROLE_CONTENT_DELETION were introduced into ATK/AT-SPI2. This change improves the accesibility of web browsers.

The notion of a "accessible identifiers" has been introduced in AT-SPI2. These are very similar to HTML IDs: like variable names, they are expected not to change much over development. This can be used e.g. by automated accessibility regression tests to identify widgets instead of relying on the textual content (which is very likely subject to changes and translations). It is also worth mentioning that AT-SPI2 can now optionally work with
dbus-broker.

As usual, the vibrant Orca community reported issues with popular software like Mozilla Firefox, Thunderbird, LibreOffice, GNOME apps, GNOME-Shell or Mate, that were in most cases fixed. In many cases, these issues were not Orca issues, but app issues or even toolkit issues. However, most of these issues were not fixed in time and Orca had to solve it by itself providing a custom script to manage these misbehaviours. This is a suboptimal solution, so it is sensible to encourage all developers to prioritize accessibilty issues to the best of its abilities.

Orca Speech Synthesis Markup Language (SSML) support has also been improved by adding progress marking support. Also, notification support has been added for letting Orca tell screen magnifiers that progress of speech synthesis, allowing the magnifier to show what is being spoken. AtkText got a new scrolling API so we can make sure that the text being spoken is actually visible for the magnifier to show it in applications like Firefox and LibreOffice.

Accerciser, the interactive accessibility explorer for the GNOME desktop, now highlights in the application the text selected in the accerciser interface, thus allowing to check the exact text positioning, which is needed for proper Mouse Review support in Orca. Orca's Mouse Review, a feature causes Orca to present the object under the mouse pointer, has received a lot of attention with improved overall presentation of units of text under the pointer or improved logic filtering out irrelevant mouse movements during review, just to mention a few improvements.

The accessibility feature Pointer Location has been updated to work under Wayland sessions now. When the feature is enabled, pressing Ctrl will highlight the pointer location on the screen.

An ATK crate has been published, this means a library that contains safe Rust bindings for ATK. This work is part of the or Gtk-rs project, that brings Rust bindings of GTK+ 3, Cairo, GtkSourceView and other GLib-compatible libraries.

The Java ATK wrapper has seen a lot of rework to make it far more reliable. There is still work needed, and some of it has to be done on the OpenJDK side, but the state is definitely much better.

events.target_title: Support touch events (panning, zooming)
control z-order of objects

note.body:
Hi Mario, every marker inherits from ClutterActor so in addition to the marker methods, you can also call all ClutterActor methods on the marker, including clutter_actor_set_z_position() which might help in your case:

https://developer.gnome.org/clutter/stable/ClutterActor.html#clutter-actor-set-z-position

However, simulating a behavior of a single marker using 3 markers isn't the cleanest way to do this. Instead, the right way is to create your own marker. If it should behave more or less like ChamplainPoint, you can inherit it from it and only override the `draw` and `pick` methods. `draw` is responsible fro drawing your marker the way you want and using `pick` you "draw" the area which is sensitive to mouse-click. Check the implementation of these methods in

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libchamplain/blob/master/champlain/champlain-point.c

for some inspiration. I'm not sure how exactly these methods are mapped to Python bindings - you'll have to find this by yourself.

events.target_title: control z-order of objects

note.body:
It's in the superclass, ChamplainMarker

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libchamplain/blob/master/champlain/champlain-marker.c

but you shouldn't need to do anything with the code.

events.target_title: control z-order of objects

note.body:
No, everything works as expected, you just misuse the API for something for which it wasn't designed. ChamplainPoint isn't meant to be a building block from which you build your custom markers with some specific behaviour - it is a location on the map which is marked by a point.

To understand why it behaves the way it does, just run the launcher-gtk demo. There are different marker types used - mostly 3 label markers, one point marker and one custom marker. Now try to drag the "New York" marker over the "Montreal" marker - notice that "New York" stays on top. Now if you click part of the "Montreal" marker behind, it's moved to the foreground which, again, is what you want. But this is exactly the bahaviour you complain about because it's not compatible with your "marker is not really used as a marker" use case.

Now I understand it's probably easier to use markers like this instead of building a custom marker. I had a look at the code which is responsible for the ordering - it's not done using z coordinates but instead by the order of marker ClutterActors within layer (which is ClutterActor too). It happens here:

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libchamplain/blob/master/champlain/champlain-marker.c#L609

So I guess you could just manually call

```
clutter_actor_set_child_above_sibling (layer, CLUTTER_ACTOR (marker1), NULL);
clutter_actor_set_child_above_sibling (layer, CLUTTER_ACTOR (marker2), NULL);
```

where `marker1` and `marker2` are the small points and `layer` is the layer where they are inserted and you will get what you want.

I'm not sure if it's interesting for you or not but you can initialize the marker layer with

```
  CHAMPLAIN_SELECTION_NONE,
  CHAMPLAIN_SELECTION_SINGLE,
  CHAMPLAIN_SELECTION_MULTIPLE
```

to disable selection, have single marker selected within layer, or have multiple markers selected.

events.target_title: create custom markers in python

note.body:
You can subclass ChamplainCustomMarker which creates an empty marker for you - the rest is up to you by adding your own ClutterActors inside, connecting clutter events etc. There's a C demo here

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libchamplain/blob/master/demos/animated-marker.c

I'm afraid I'm not so much familiar with Python bindings of libchamplain and clutter so I can't give any python-specific advice but there's no reason why you shouldn't be able to do everything in Python.

events.target_title: control z-order of objects

note.body:
You can find the python binding names from the libchamplain gir file:

```
   <enumeration name="SelectionMode"
                 glib:type-name="ChamplainSelectionMode"
                 glib:get-type="champlain_selection_mode_get_type"
                 c:type="ChamplainSelectionMode">
      <doc xml:space="preserve">Selection mode</doc>
      <member name="none"
              value="0"
              c:identifier="CHAMPLAIN_SELECTION_NONE"
              glib:nick="none">
        <doc xml:space="preserve">No marker can be selected.</doc>
      </member>
      <member name="single"
              value="1"
              c:identifier="CHAMPLAIN_SELECTION_SINGLE"
              glib:nick="single">
        <doc xml:space="preserve">Only one marker can be selected.</doc>
      </member>
      <member name="multiple"
              value="2"
              c:identifier="CHAMPLAIN_SELECTION_MULTIPLE"
              glib:nick="multiple">
        <doc xml:space="preserve">Multiple marker can be selected.</doc>
      </member>
    </enumeration>
```

So e.g. CHAMPLAIN_SELECTION_NONE should be mapped to SelectionMode.none.

I've checked and the z-position calls aren't used anywhere in libchamplain and I'm not completely sure how they work.

Creating a custom marker the "right" way will definitely be more work than your current slightly hacky approach - the question is whether it's worth all the work if you can find a workaround for your problems.

events.target_title: Suboptimal window drawing on Windows

note.body:
Hi,
I'm a developer of GTK+-based cross-platform application.
I've had CSD enabled in Windows builds and got feedback about how ugly, alien and out-of-place the application looks on Windows. Right now I'm forcing CSD=off in Windows and everybody's happy.

Please, please, don't force CSD on us. The users don't care which toolkit the developer has chosen as long as the application looks nice and consistent with the rest of their desktop. I certainly would not want Windows-style window decorations (or controls) on my Linux desktop. Forcing CSD reminds me of the old Windows bitmap-UI applications. All the other toolkits can do SSD, why can't GTK+ do it?

Thanks,
Alexander

events.target_title: Suboptimal window drawing on Windows

note.body:
> You can make GTK look more consistent with Windows by using a Windows GTK theme.

I remember having to force GTK_CSD=0, even though I had GTK+ Windows theme enabled. I think it was due to ugly titlebars on win8+.
As a side note, GTK+ Windows theme is broken when used with Windows 7 Classic theme, even basic controls like checkboxes don't work. I had to force Adwaita (with CSD=0) under Windows 7 to avoid a completely broken GUI. There is a bug report for this.

> Someone mentioned "Windows 10 Gtk3 theme by b00merang Project" on the mailing list.

The b00merang theme supports X11-based desktops, not Gtk/Windows.
It is also not designed to follow the Windows color scheme.

> Gnome is generally option-averse these days

There are GTK+-using developers outside of the Gnome project (like me), who just want to use GTK+ as a cross-platform toolkit.
Besides, Windows users are likely to use individual GTK+ applications, rather than Gnome.

events.target_title: Suboptimal window drawing on Windows

note.body:
The question is, do applications actually use this transparency?
I believe we should not sacrifice the look and behavior of overwhelming majority of applications for the other 1% (if even that).

events.target_title: Meld not working, says "pango_font_description_set_size: assertion 'size >= 0' failed"
Meld not working, says "pango_font_description_set_size: assertion 'size >= 0' failed"

note.body:
OK so I found the culprit. As a HiDPI display user I had the following environment variables set:
GDK_SCALE=2
GDK_DPI_SCALE=-1.

Apparently, meld doesn't like GDK_DPI_SCALE=-1 (setting it to 0.5 makes meld work).
Some sources say we should use GDK_DPI_SCALE=-1 for "automatic", but turns out it's not documented in GTK.

Anyway, I don't think it's a bug in Meld per se.

Thanks

note.body:
You mean to upgrade to GLib 2.56.0? I will try and report back. Will the fix be backported to 2.54?

Are you sure that the commit and bug you referenced are related? The [second build.log](https://bugs.gentoo.org/attachment.cgi?id=524258) attached to the [Gentoo bug][1] shows this as the issue:
```
In file included from gtkmarshal.c:1097:0:
gtkaliasdef.c:5933:48: error: redefinition of ‘gtk_marshal_BOOLEAN__POINTER’
 extern __typeof (gtk_marshal_BOOLEAN__POINTER) gtk_marshal_BOOLEAN__POINTER __attribute((alias("IA__gtk_marshal_BOOLEAN__POINTER"), visibility("default")));
                                                ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
gtkmarshal.c:91:1: note: previous definition of ‘gtk_marshal_BOOLEAN__POINTER’ was here
 gtk_marshal_BOOLEAN__POINTER (GClosure     *closure,
 ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
```

And that is the result of wrong capitalisation of header guards in `gtk.symbols` (files generated by `glib-genmarshal` from glib-2.54.3 use upper-case header guards, while previous versions used lower-case header guards), which is still present in [the commit you referenced][2].

[1]: https://bugs.gentoo.org/650536
[2]: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/f14fbca64509a5b79607f20ecbbe69239eb24e15/gtk/gtk.symbols#L2501

events.target_title: Make CSD window shadows available on KDE

note.body:
> It's unclear how this would even work on Wayland.

On Wayland we use an equivalent custom protocol. Note that both of these methods are mainly used by shell chrome windows and popups, where Plasma code and the Qt style plugin are decorating, respectively. In the case of top-level windows the shadow is done by the KWin window decoration plugin.

In my eyes the ideal outcome is visual consistency for the shadows of at least top-level windows. Rather than GTK+ uploading shadow pixmaps, I think the way forward would be:

a) GTK+ making use of the xdg-toplevel-decoration protocol currently under review on wayland-devel (it looks like a likely merge, and GTK+ already has some support for an earlier version of the protocol) to negotiate server-side decorations when the compositor advertises support and a preference for them

b) When having negotiated server-side decorations with the compositor, GtkHeaderBar is styled as/more like a toolbar and doesn't show window management controls

The shadow is then done by KWin, and all is lovely for top-levels.

That still leaves us to figure out shadows for popups, though. GTK+ could use our shadow protocol there, or something like it - this could need more work on wayland-devel in the future.

--Eike, Plasma

events.target_title: Scale's drag circle is offset from the actual mouse position if the scale's value is displayed on its left
Scale does not automatically show the custom ::format-value

note.body:
I can get it to display the correct string if I first intialize the Scale to have a NULL adjustment, then connect the signal, then set it to a new adjustment. But then you can't really use `gtk_scale_new_with_range` for convenience.

I came across this problem when loading from a builder file, which contains both the scale and its adjustment. To get around it I ended up just forcing a change in its value. But this is a bit risky since 'changing' the adjustment value to the same value won't emit the "value-changed" signal. So really you would need to change the value twice before displaying.

Since this is not a problem in gtk+3, what feature was removed that would originally handle this?

It did have the same effect in GNOME Disks, but I have just managed to solve this for myself.
The unencrypted partition was using FAT, whilst the encrypted part used ext4. So I chown'ed the entire ext4 partition to 1000, and it now works, even after a reboot.

But given this, I no longer think this could be a GNOME bug.

Thank you anyway, because your reply prompted me to look into udisks, and even though I didn't do anything with udisks, this still led me to the solution.

events.target_title: While composing plain text messages, allow switching between flowed text mode and fixed-columns mode
While composing plain text messages, allow switching between flowed text mode and fixed-columns mode

note.body:
Hi Michael,

Maybe I was a little misleading, I wanted to propose a single message-wide format flag. Actually I would rather always use flowed text, but fixed-columns seems to be important for RFC compliance [1], and I'm sure some plain-text writers prefer it.

I agree that implementing paragraph-wise format flagging could be daunting and I think it may end up also not being used frequently enough; speaking for myself only, I have never seen such a feature :'D

[1]: http://www.faqs.org/rfcs/rfc2646.html

EDIT: spelling, grammar

events.target_title: While composing plain text messages, allow switching between flowed text mode and fixed-columns mode

note.body:
Yeah, I think wrapping fixed-columns text is a bad idea. I think however, that it could optionally be displayed with wrapping disabled.

And about RFC 2646, I meant that there is a recognized flag that plain text emails can contain, stating whether the plain text format is "fixed" or "flowed", of which "fixed" is the default, and Geary is currently only supporting "flowed" format.

events.target_title: While composing plain text messages, allow switching between flowed text mode and fixed-columns mode

note.body:
> Well in RFC 2646 (and actually RFC 3676, which obsoletes that), specifying "fixed" is the same as specifying no format param, which as I mentioned is bad because it badly breaks wrapped text. Check [the example in the RFC](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2646#section-3.2) to see what I mean.

I understand that wrapping "fixed" format text results in unwanted behaviour, which is why I suggest that in general "fixed" format text should be displayed with wrapping disabled.

>  Do you have a specific use-case for wanting to disable it? It would be good to not add code that makes Geary send out embarrassingly quoted email unless there's a good reason for it. :)

Well, as I said I always use flowed text myself, just thought it would be a nice to have feature, for the sake of completeness only. So I don't have a specific use-case where it would be necessary. I recall I once read that "fixed" format was better for people who sent coding patches by email, but I couldn't find it anymore. So well, things ought to be kept simple, and I guess until somebody is able to justify reasonably the need for "fixed" format text, things shall be left as they are.

events.target_title: Add GNOME GitLab CI builds

note.body:
IIRC, https://cgit.freedesktop.org/NetworkManager/NetworkManager/commit/?id=f6272144e98c00db18cf6708aceab96e6e7b1705 is necessary to build with `-O0`. If the same check would be applied in NetworkManager, you could no longer build `--enable-introspection`, `--enable-more-warnings=error` and `CFLAGS=-O0`. Which is what I usually do. You still can fail configure, but only after the configure check fails with `-Wno-error`. Note that below, introspection.m4 already contains the line
```
AC_SUBST(INTROSPECTION_SCANNER, 'CFLAGS="${CFLAGS} -Wno-error" '"$INTROSPECTION_SCANNER")
```
that adjustment of CFLAGs would be useless, if you previously already failed configure in case of warnings.
