events.target_title: Sound for (Google) Calendar notifications?

note.body:
My bad wording - plays sound.

Tested in Fedora 28 with Evolution 3.28.5, and heard no sound on notification, with selected calendars and  tested with both "Display notifications in notification area only" on and off. 

Getting an e-mail does play a sound, oddly enough.

Other sounds work perfectly fine on my desktop. The only thing I had to change on my desktop for sounds was `load-module module-udev-detect` to `load-module module-udev-detect tsched=0` in `/etc/pulse/default.pa`.

events.target_title: Sound for (Google) Calendar notifications?
Sound for (Google) Calendar notifications?

note.body:
OK. Synced Google Calendar with Evolution. 

**What I expected:** whenever an event happens in my Google Calendar, I get a notification *with sound*.

**What happened:** I got a notification, but *no sound*.

**Scenario 1:**
-Go to Edit->Preferences->Calendars and tasks->Reminders

-Check on my calendar of preference

-Go to Calendar view

-Right-click on my calendar of preference -> refresh

-Wait for notification

-Notification pops in tray, but there's no sound played.

**Scenario 2:**
-Go to Edit->Preferences->Calendars and tasks->Reminders

-Check on my calendar of preference

-Uncheck "Display notifications in notification area only"

-Go to Calendar view

-Right-click on my calendar of preference -> refresh

-Wait for notification

-Notification pops up, but there's no sound played.

events.target_title: mouse and sloppy focus defeat alt-tab
mouse and sloppy focus defeat alt-tab

note.body:
It's not at all clear that the two issue management systems are redundant (why would they both be in use?), or that they both get the same level of attention.  It is obvious that I knew about the bugzilla report since I cited it, so the closure comment was notably unhelpful.

I appreciate that the issue is low priority. However, this is an instance where ninety seconds of attention by a knowledgeable dev could save a novice like me hours of work, namely in finding the relevant project module and source files, and perhaps in identifying why the regression was introduced or summarizing what is already known to the team about the constraints that confound fixing it.  There is no such discussion in bugzilla. (I was in the process of writing a question to that effect when the issue was closed out from under me.)  

In any case, I probably lack the expertise required to solve this problem, so my extra eyeballs are useless and it probably *is* going to turn out to be a waste of your time that I opened the issue. sorry.

note.body:
Unfortunately the project that causes the crash is private, so I'm glad you were able to reproduce the issue.  I did try the nightly build right after I got this issue and I was unable to get that one to run for any projects, but I can try it again.  For the other two nodejs projects I'm running, it does eventually become responsive (after maybe 20-30 seconds).

Can you give me an idea of what Builder is doing during startup that makes it unresponsive for these projects?

BTW I just want to let you know that the 3.28 version of Builder is really great for working with javascript.

events.target_title: Builder crashes when launching a nodejs project

note.body:
So I tried an updated nightly build and got it running.  This is version 3.29.1-178-gf9bd244
flatpak-nightly.  I tried to load the codebase again and it still ran out of memory and is basically unresponsive for several minutes before it dies.  I killed it when it started churning through my 16GB of swap space.

Just to describe the repo in question, it contains a client-side angular app and a backend express server app.  The client-side app is 275M total and has 26,683 files, 254M and 26,282 are from node_modules.  The backend app is 612M total with 70,700 files, 115M and 16,595 is from node_modules.  But in that folder there are also two checked out other projects that take up about 495M with 53,951 files.  

So it's a lot of files in this checked out repository (yay javascript).  Total files is over 1GB and over 100K files.

events.target_title: Builder crashes when launching a nodejs project

note.body: Is there any way to reduce the amount of work the indexer is doing or get it to ignore certain directories?  I'd be just as happy working with it if it ignored node_modules and just indexed the source files I care about.  At least that way I could actually use it, while right now it's only sometimes usable for small javascript projects.

events.target_title: Builder crashes when launching a nodejs project

note.body:
OK so this is pretty interesting.  So this morning I was poking around in the preferences and noticed the Extensions tab.  I turned everything off and reloaded my big project and it ran just fine.  It was immediately responsive and did not infinitely load memory.  I started enabling extensions one by one and it was only when I enabled the `To-Do Tracker` that the system started to choke.  My guess is that this extension is checking every single source file in the project for TODOs.

So I disabled that extension and everything else is enabled and its working great now.

note.body: As a user, I care more about not burning CPU and battery life than about 3D transforms.

events.target_title: Geometric (OpenGL-less) picking

note.body:
> There is the alternative solution that @feaneron has been working on making the cogl journal always to be used. That would also improve performance.

By the same amount?

> I don't see the reason for landing this this early in the cycle

Landing early sounds like a good way to flush out regressions.

> we can avoid regressing in what we can pick

What user-facing functionality in Gnome is regressed by the inability to pick actors affected by 3D transforms? What's best for the users?

events.target_title: Geometric (OpenGL-less) picking

note.body:
> I can't remember whether there are any comparison of what approach provides a more efficient solution.

Unless proven otherwise, I don't think involving the GPU here can be as efficient as avoiding it.

> We'll (GNOME Shell, and every other user of libmutter) loose the ability to implement various types of compositor effects

Until you find a use for this functionality, Gnome Shell burns a lot of CPU and power for something that's not needed. It's sluggish enough anyway, and there's no GS4 in sight, so I'd argue that you _need_ every performance improvement you can get. _Read some of the user feedback: people aren't complaining that they can't interact with windows while flying around a 3D cube, they're complaining that Gnome is slow, and that their mouse cursor lags under load._

> why rush in one that does regress

Because these fixes are long overdue, and this MR has been in limbo for some 8 months already.

---

Anyway, I realize this is coming off a little aggressive, and I apologize for that. I'm just a dissatisfied user who can't contribute in any meaningful technical way.

Thanks @vanvugt for pushing with this changes.

events.target_title: OSK: [Xorg] Unable to type capital letters
wacom cintiq 15 x pl 550 is not recongnized by ubuntu 18.04, how can calibrate it and set buttons?

note.body:
Cinnamon's control panel is based on the GNOME one, both of which rely on the "libwacom" library to provide the information necessary to configure buttons and calibrate. The libwacom library itself doesn't currently have support for the PL-550, so I find it very curious that you were able to see your tablet in Mint's control panel.

Regardless, please run the linuxwacom project's [sysinfo.sh script](https://github.com/linuxwacom/wacom-hid-descriptors/blob/master/scripts/sysinfo.sh) and attach the generated tarball to a new issue filed on their [wacom-hid-descriptors bug tracker](https://github.com/linuxwacom/wacom-hid-descriptors/issues). They should be able to use the information gathered to generate a tablet definition for libwacom which you can test out.

events.target_title: Memory leak

note.body:
Regarding the "rewrite it in Rust" comment: that wasn't *just* for the purpose of dealing with memory leaks. It seems like Gnome Shell has a lot of design/architecture issues that cause problems, and a proposal for a Gnome Shell 4 has already been put forward: https://wiki.gnome.org/Initiatives/Wayland/GnomeShell/GnomeShell4

Unfortunately, I am not aware of any further news regarding this initiative. If a rewrite is going to be inevitable anyway to deal with improving the software architecture, I think it would make sense to use a safer language such as Rust wherever possible. It might not be a magic wand, but it certainly makes things significantly safer.

events.target_title: Improve standard header bar layouts

note.body:
In my personal opinion as an end user, I prefer the current approach to headerbars. It seems clear and organised: as said in the OP, there is a standard layout with a main feature in the middle, and buttons on either side. This looks good, clean, and creates a lot of consistency. I also appreciate the separator line next to the close button, as that button serves a special purpose and looks better being divided off like that.

When I look at the mockups, the huge spacing between icons just looks bad to me.  
In terms of aesthetics: It looks like the icons have just been strewn across the headerbar with no rhyme or reason, and there's no longer any organisation or structure to it. It looks like they're just randomly placed everywhere with huge gaps all over the place.  
In terms of usability: The large distance between icons makes it harder for me to follow visually. They're all just standalone, separated icons, and I have to mentally jump from each one and process it individually. With the current headerbars, they seem logically grouped and I can scan over them all at once and process them together as a group.

events.target_title: panel: Remove panel translucency

note.body:
I would very much appreciate it if the code for this could remain, while just being optional. Disable it by default if need be - but why remove it entirely when it works?

As others have stated, it is a very small number of people that would be negatively affected by this. It's very much a niche corner case, and if/when it does become a problem, there are still other areas of GNOME Shell that are affected in exactly the same way already (e.g. search results on the overlay screen), so it doesn't even completely solve the issue. To completely solve it, you'd need a solid black background on the overlay screen as well. [See here.](https://i.imgur.com/vr1v7oV.png)

This change negatively affects the 99%, while only *partially* solving a problem for the 1%. And really, that "problem" is just user error. There is only an issue with legibility if the user manually changes their wallpaper to one that makes the text hard to read. Distros are unlikely to choose such a wallpaper themselves. If a user manually changes their wallpaper to one that causes a usability problem, surely they will realise that and just change their wallpaper back, or willingly put up with it? Why is it GNOME's job to deal with this?

To me, this change seems like it would be more suited to a specific "high contrast" mode, as we have with the HighContrast variant theme of Adwaita. People with special visual needs use high contrast themes to deal with issues like this, while the vast majority of people can work perfectly fine with beautiful and colourful designs.

The current top bar looks beautiful when transparent, and also makes the desktop appear more spacious and less cramped. It makes the desktop feel more friendly and more joyful to use.

While an extension might be able to do the same thing, I personally don't like the idea that it doesn't matter since an extension can do it. With that reasoning, GNOME Shell itself might as well have zero features since extensions can do it all. The problems with extensions are that they are often less trustworthy, being maintained by third parties, they often go out of date or become abandoned, they won't necessarily be carefully designed by the GNOME team for polish and consistency, they can cause stability issues such as shell crashes. I proudly run GNOME with zero extensions for maximum stability, and I'd very much like to keep it that way.

events.target_title: Calendar uses Dark theme variant under night-light

note.body:
I realise from this bug report that this has been in place for several months, but I am in favour of reverting this. As a new user to GNOME Calendar, I found this behaviour to be bizarre. I assumed it was a bug, but I've now learnt that it's actually an intended feature, and it makes no sense to me. Even more worryingly, it seems like this is a direction GNOME is heading in overall.

The thing is, this makes no sense, especially as a hard-coded default. The ideal colour scheme to use is one that matches the lighting in your environment. There have been studies on this. The idea is that the colours of your monitor should be similar to the colours of your room behind/around the monitor. That is what gives the least eye strain:

1. If the environment has **sunlight**, then you should have a **light theme** with **default monitor colours**.
2. If the environment has **artificial lighting**, then you should have a **light theme** with **red-shifted monitor colours** (i.e. Night Light).
3. If the environment has **little/no lighting**, then you should have a **dark theme** with **dimmed and red-shifted monitor colours**.

What GNOME seems to be doing is thinking that in scenario 2 you want a dark theme, which is just wrong. If you're in a well-lit environment, a light theme is better suited to reduce eye strain. You only need a dark theme if you're in a dark room. When Night Light is active, that doesn't mean you're in a dark room, but just that it's late in the day and the sun is down. Normally in this situation, you'll have your indoor lighting turned on and therefore would want a light theme.

Found how to solve it, thanks to [Archlinux forum](https://bbs.archlinux.org/viewtopic.php?pid=1775953). The issue was related with [system monitor extension](https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/120/system-monitor/), after disabling it, gnome-shell no longer crash.

I think, gnome shell should not crash, preventing user to get into UI, because of an misbehaving extension. And I thing this is Gnome shell bug.

events.target_title: After upgrading to 3.28 gnome shell won't start

note.body:
Probably it is ok, if for example Firefox would crash because of extension, I can still be able to use my laptop, but when gnome-shell crashes because of extension, I no longer can use my laptop. I think it's pretty bad.

Gnome-shell must start at any cost. If an exstension chrashed it, then probably gnome-shell should disable all exstentions and then try to start again.

events.target_title: Segmentation fault on Python 3.6 when running GStreamer on OSX

note.body:
It does look like the issue is isolated to conda python pygobject, so I have raised an issue with the team maintaining that distribution - it is also quite repeatable, the pip and the conda versions installed in the same conda environment both behave the same way. I have raised an issue with the maintainers of the conda recipe to see if they are facing the same problem.

The reason why we are using conda is because we can easily package simpler environments that have well-understood binary library requirements: eg. numpy and opencv, and it does seem to play nicer with packaging environments for statistics. Also, a few products such as Amazon SageMaker and General Electric Predix use conda (or Anaconda) as their package manager for python.

events.target_title: Mac build fails with glib.h static assertion

note.body:
> That particular assertion should not fail if glib's compile-time-generated `glibconfig.h` used portable definitions for the types. Currently it contains:
>
>
> ```
> typedef signed long gint64;
> typedef unsigned long guint64;
> ```
> which works as expected on x86_64 but defines a 32-bit type on i386.
>
>
> There are probably other things that would be different between the two arches -- other types like the `gssize` type, and the `printf` formatting strings for each of those types, for instance.
>
>
> Instead of hardcoding them they could be wrapped in preprocessor checks for which architecture is being compiled to. I'm not sure how hard it would be to adjust that in the generation of the header file...

FYI, MacPorts has for years been patching glib to fix these problems, using [this patch](https://github.com/macports/macports-ports/blob/master/devel/glib2/files/universal.patch) applied before running autoreconf, and [this ed script](https://github.com/macports/macports-ports/blob/master/devel/glib2/files/config.h.ed) run after running configure.

Unfortunately, these patches are not suitable as-is for inclusion in upstream glib, and I don't have the time or inclination to rework them for inclusion upstream, and neither do the developers of glib. In the mean time, glib has moved from autotools to meson, and I have no idea what the situation with universal builds is there.

note.body:
So, curious: I'm running Lollypop on Arch.  I am _certainly_ on a GTK version that is higher than 3.18 (3.22, to be exact).  

My playlist doesn't spew the errors mentioned, but I also don't get any playlists.  Should I?  

One of the playlists is the best songs of every album I own (1200 albums), so it's mid-3000 entries.  No way I'm rebuilding that...

events.target_title: the application should create a playlist for any m3u file

note.body:
It wasn't quite as easy as all that.  I ended up having several hundred files "missing".

I don't know what library is being used to URLencode the entries, but it is very... inconsistent.  

It doesn't encode characters like ?,.-$!... basically, any "normal" key on an English keyboard doesn't get URLEncoded.

But all spaces do get turned into %20, and _some_ of the more nonstandard, more complex characters do, such as: ★,Æ,à,á,é,ó,Ó,ä,ö,ü,ÿ,å,°,²,â,®.

After lots of reverse engineering and relatively basic Bash scripting, I came up with the attached utility.  I don't consider it complete, but I consider it complete enough to properly import my lengthy playlists _mostly_ accurately.

Maybe it will be of use to you when you implement, or to someone else.  It could probably use a larger mapping -- I didn't exactly have a reference in front of me, and though I have a sizable collection I doubt it's use of special characters is comprehensive.  

This script accepts any m3u you throw at it, but it expects one from iTunes and has stanzas in it to clean out the #EXTINF lines iTunes likes to throw in there.  It also sorts the list, so if you're not into that, don't run it.  ;-)

It could probably be polished up to accept more arguments -- it currently needs two:

./lollypop-playlist-creator.sh $Your_M3U_File_location $Your_Playlist_number

Your playlist number is something you'll have to pull from the database, but typically the first one you created is "1" and the second one is "2", etc. etc.

[lollypop-playlist-creator.sh](/uploads/d9251cefa8a5e03f6ba810522bcdd428/lollypop-playlist-creator.sh)

events.target_title: the application should create a playlist for any m3u file

note.body: ...one more thing.  Lollypop freezes, hard, whenever you try to add a track containing [ or ] to any playlist.  (If it's already in the DB, it just doesn't show up in the playlist).  Should I open a separate bug for that?  I don't think the behavior is intended.

events.target_title: the application should create a playlist for any m3u file

note.body:
...and all this, to find out that Playlists cannot be shuffled.  *sigh*

Oh, well.  It was a fun exercise regardless.

note.body:
#### Regarding the publishing platform: 
As @sendz said, a possible solution is to use a static content generator. Also **AppImage** uses this approach: https://github.com/AppImage/appimage.github.io

Another solution could be one of my archived project: *Softhub* is an open source app-store built with Django 1.10, Python 3+ and Bootstrap. If you find it interesting, we can re-use all or part of the code.
You can take a peek at this quick [video overview](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sRPfpDk9aDg) or see the code in the Gitlab repo [here](https://gitlab.com/davcri91/softhub-site).

note.body:
Wow guys the discussion is really interesting!

What about creating separate issues (IDK if it's okay to do it in here) to discuss the topics?

1. *Landing page structure*: the one proposed by @ebassi is an excellent starting point. Can we improve it? How?
1. *Landing page content*: we need new screenshots and updated/new text. The focus here is to give light to the GTK "brand": which are the major selling points of GTK? Does it have a [tagline](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tagline) or a slogan ? 
1. Very simple *Mockups*: before implementing something, it would nice to have some mockups so we can prototype and iterate. What do you think?
1. *Technology stack*: static content seems the way, but which system to use? I have experience with Hugo and Jekyll (both uses markdown content files), but I have no problem in using other technologies. What about the CSS ? Shall we use lightweight pure standard CSS, Bootstrap 4,...?

Improvements to "Proprietary" pop box text to make it more informative about Free software

note.body: As had been commented on the Fedora Workstation mailing list where this discussion began, the message can be educational without making a user "feel bad". As I also pointed out there, "proprietary" does not give the user sufficient "information" and so, the attempt at rephrasing to improve the information content.

events.target_title: Would it be possible to user Free software terminolgy to mark non-free software?  "NonFree" instead of "Proprietary" for example

note.body: Sure. Luckily it's free software and distributions can even patch it if necessary. My understanding was that Gnome, like Fedora, is a project that aims to further Free software via the great suite of software it produces. So, this ticket has been filed in the hope that Gnome will do more, and keep the philosophy in the UI here.

events.target_title: Would it be possible to user Free software terminolgy to mark non-free software?  "NonFree" instead of "Proprietary" for example

note.body:
Thanks for chiming in, Matthew. I do understand the issues with "non free" and the other terms. Luckily, discussion around terminology isn't new in the Free software community. Ubuntu, for example already does what Fedora is doing now (sort of), and they use the term "Restricted" as one of their repository classifications. How does that sound? It means the same thing, but is clearer on the lack of freedom? I'd think it's easier to translate into various languages too, since it's a more general term? 

Reference: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/Repositories/Ubuntu

I'm still trying to find the discussion that led to the use of the term, but it was years ago and is buried somewhere on the WWW.

Yes, I've opened another ticket about the hover text too, so even if we can't use "Restricted" (or another term) instead of "Proprietary", we should at least work on that. :)

note.body:
The problematic file has been narrowed down to ~/.config/autostart/vivaldi-stable.desktop, which is apparently not encoded in UTF-8. Byte 230 of it is 0xD9, apparently corresponding to some encoding of Armenian (GenericName[ar]=متص<D9>?ح الشبكة) for "Web Browser". I have no idea what the encoding is, some form of ISO-8859?

Am now trying to find out if the upstream vivaldi packagers can recode it to UTF-8.

Still, this should not be able to kill gnome-tweaks.

events.target_title: X11: Drop-down menus from menu bar don't react to touchscreen taps

note.body: I did some research and it appears to be triggered by the presence of TOUCH_EVENTS in gdkseatdefault.c, rather than the absence of POINTER_EVENTS. If you or-in both TOUCH_EVENTS and POINTER_EVENTS together then the touchscreen won't work the menu - if you set to POINTER_EVENTS only then the touchscreen will work.

events.target_title: X11: Drop-down menus from menu bar don't react to touchscreen taps

note.body:
I had an extended poke around to try and work this out, but made very limited progress.

The touch event never gets into gtk_menu_shell_button_press/gtk_menu_shell_button_release and so the menu item is not activated.

This lack of button events is something to do with the pointer grab the menu does, because if popup_grab_on_window in gtkmenu.c is defanged with an early return statement, then the menu will get button events (from the touch events), and the menu will work seemingly as normal on touch. This explains why a touch can open a menu but not select any items on the menu - the grab only happens once the menu is opened.

events.target_title: can't write cd audio

note.body:
Thanks for the workaround, Brian! `sudo chmod -v 4711 /usr/bin/wodim` makes wodim setuid root, which solved the problem for me. It looks like wodim has to be run as root, because otherwise trying to write an audio CD immediately fails with a dialog saying "Error while burning. An unknown error occurred." and the following lines in the log:

```
BraseroWodim stderr: wodim: Operation not permitted. Warning: Cannot raise RLIMIT_MEMLOCK limits.
BraseroWodim called brasero_job_get_flags
BraseroWodim stderr: wodim: Resource temporarily unavailable. Cannot get mmap for 16781312 Bytes on /dev/zero.
BraseroWodim called brasero_job_get_flags
BraseroWodim stdout: TOC Type: 0 = CD-DA
BraseroWodim stderr: HUP
BraseroWodim stdout: HUP
BraseroWodim process finished with status 11
BraseroWodim called brasero_job_error
BraseroWodim finished with an error
BraseroWodim asked to stop because of an error
        error           = 0
        message = "no message"
BraseroWodim stopping
Session error : unknown (brasero_burn_record brasero-burn.c:2859)
```

The out of the box experience was pretty bad. Brasero should inform the user about the permission problem, or use something else than wodim if there's an alternative that doesn't require root privileges.

note.body:
@daenney Quote from #81:

> Oh dear. Though rendering in Y-tiled formats is more optimal, it takes up more resources in the display controller's FIFO. In this case, using Y-tiling (which we get from declared modifiers) for both displays requires more room than is available. There's no way to detect this: I think the best we could do is, if we detect that a modeset failed and we're using modifiers, blacklist the one we were using and keep trying until it succeeds.
